we have
for the past year.
It is not much
of a system but at least we know
to depend
on our own efforts and we act accordingly. I do not put much
trust in anything else just now.
Regarding your suggestion that it might be possible to carry
Hongkong and make enough off of the exchange
considered several such schemes but they are not practicable. Our planes
have to pass a
very rigid Customs
inspection now both at Chungking going and coming
and also in Hongkong by Chinese Inspectors.
Also the Chinese
Government has taken
over all import
and export business and you must have a permit for each shipment.
We would have to have a permit for each shipment, giving all details and the
must be in foreign currency.
Collections must be paid,
in foreign currency to the
Ministry of Finance,
Central Trust, who will remit to the shipper or vendor in
National Currency at
the official
The profit on the exchenge goes to the
Ministry of Finance.
Regarding the Clipper continuing to fly into HOngkong I agree with you
situation has not been changed by the occupation of
South China and
no change in policy is called for. In fact
as you say as the Japanese move
into South China there will be less flying around over the ocean by Japanese planes.
and the Clipper will
come in behind the flying.
However this is only a
principle and
does not cover all the details. The Japanese navy no doubt will continue to have
outside and will
fly planes from it.
That is certain but at least the
situation is no worse. However since you asked me I
would like to offet one
suggestion.
I understand PAA does not advise the Japanese in anyway regarding their
schedules and flights.
I may be misinformed but anyway I think they
should. I do
not think any sovereign right is
involved nor would I be too much of a stickler
if it was.
I am in complete disagreement with those who maintain that since no
war has been there declared there is no war and the Japanese auxx cannot do certain
things which they might have the right to do if war had been declared.
entirely by what I have seen I am convinced there is a war and the theorist can say
what they
Also the war is absolutely vital to the Japanese and they are
taking it very
Also in spite of many cases of individual, and collective,
brutality, I think on the whole they have respected the rights of Americans as much
as the Germans or the English did before we got into the world war, and probably mon
than the French and English did after we got into it. However that is not important.
If PAA regularly advises
the Japanese of their schedules and flights in my opinion
it will be a very decided added safety factor and that is of the utmost importance.
Regarding Allison I can easily understand how difficult it is for PAA to
place kin a man of his position on short notice.
Allison appreciates
that but the offer which PAA did make him immediately after the war was made at a
time when his wife was having a baby and everything was in confusion and it not
register very
clearly with him at that time and unfortunately it never has properly
Allie has a rather single track mind as you know. An admirable taait
in some respects but rather difficult at times in others.
I have told him that
if and when he
to the States he goes to see PAA he will be surprised
at the cordial welcome he will get and pleased with the efforts that will be made
in his behalf.
I guess that covers.
raid alarm here has sounded
lettethis
building is
bomb proof.
K anch
